name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @satofishi I would much rather see the BTC community come to appreciate the virtues of PoS on their own ‚ò∫Ô∏è

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @icebearhww The answer to books vs music is different! Back in ~2011-12 I read the standard Austrian econ canon (Mises, Rothbard...) and that shaped my thinking a lot and made me appreciate BTC early on, though since then I've moved further away from that school of thought in particular

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @jemenger @ESYudkowsky @GiveWell But also important are "anti-influences", like seeing how toxic BTC maximalism was becoming even back in 2013 and wanting to build a culture that's far away from being like that.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @tylercowen The latter because I'm thinking about stablecoins. Some people think stablecoins are purely transition tech, and post-hypercryptoization BTC or ETH will be stable. I think there's a big chance this is wrong and even post-hypercryptoization we would still need explicit stablecoins

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @tylercowen I feel like I've been doing less "monetary theory" per se than a few years ago! I just don't rate it as anywhere close to the world's most important problem the way I would 10 years ago or the way many BTC people do today.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BitcoinMoon11 7 years ago, before ethereum even began, I had only a few thousand dollars of net worth. I nevertheless sold half my bitcoin to make sure that I would not be broke if BTC went to zero.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @GeorgeSelgin "Is BTC money" is not a question of economics, it's a question of signaling: "do bitcoiners get to plant their flag on this proud metaphorical hill where USD, EUR, CNY live"?  If you want to talk about economics, you have to credibly signal that you're not talking about the hill.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @JavierGonzalez @btcfork @CollinEnstad Yeah, I get that what I'm saying is the social contract of ETH, and it's not the social contract of BCH. It *is* arguably the social contract of BTC (see: their support of UASFs) though. And maybe it's the social contract of BCHA too?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @gladstein @deeeedle @lopp @twobitidiot @HRF Also there is a systemic concern: if the bulk of BTC economic activity is institutional then those institutions may well become a de facto governance layer and could be co-opted by nation state actors. Dissenters could fork off, but keep what percent of the value of their assets?
reply_to: [{'screen_name': 'gladstein', 'name': 'Alex Gladstein üåã ‚ö°', 'id': '19721574'}, {'screen_name': 'deeeedle', 'name': 'Dan Edlebeck ‚öõÔ∏è', 'id': '20197421'}, {'screen_name': 'lopp', 'name': 'Jameson Lopp', 'id': '23618940'}, {'screen_name': 'twobitidiot', 'name': 'Ryan Selkis', 'id': '2193616844'}, {'screen_name': 'HRF', 'name': 'Human Rights Foundation', 'id': '57041360'}]

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @Excellion Dude, you're literally part of a company that created a proprietary consortium chain for people to stick their tokens onto that only needs to exist because BTC (and even trustless L2s on top of it) don't have the scalability or functionality to do so natively.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @mysticryuujin I think it's BTC people that call them lite.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @blogofjake > I was under the impression one would need to acquire >50% of all existing BTC  No. You only need to acquire an amount roughly equal to a few months to a year worth of mining revenue.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @austerity_sucks @zhusu I'm still pro-crypto because my own vision for what a crypto-dominant world would looks like does not involve crypto becoming the UoA. We already see things being paid in BTC/ETH but denominated in USD.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @eric_lombrozo @danheld > It seems you are confusing prescriptive and descriptive terminology.  I'd say pointing out a correlation between prescriptive views and descriptive views that I noticed.  eg. I haven't see anyone express the viewpoint "I think BTC will absorb all value and that's a big tragedy"

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: PayPal customers will be able to use BTC, ETH and other cryptos to pay merchants.   https://t.co/6qhkVuEyF4  Welcome to the @ethereum ecosystem, @PayPal!

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @awayslice There are many versions of USD, BTC and ETH on ethereum. Whichever you consider money you can use!

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BlockGeekDima @alexblue_99 @Bitcoin @ethereum Ah, but does it have constant-product post-neoliberal sharded hydroxychloroquine yield farming?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @Degenify The choice of BTC was deliberate; I'm trying out a hypothesis that bitcoin people specifically are more likely to interpret me as a socialist

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: Let me try a correlation poll.  1. Do you hold any BTC? (Y/N) 2. Do the ideas that I promote and seem to hold tend to be more capitalist (C) or socialist (S)?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @AriDavidPaul Agree it doesn't work with BTC and ETH and the like (heck, even BSV is still limping....). But it does work somewhat more with fly-by-night pyramid coins that appear quickly and die quickly.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @vinarmani @deadalnix > Nakamoto Consensus eliminates the necessity of a social contract.  Umm... the BCH social contract is the only reason why BCH clients don't immediately just reorg onto the hashpower-dominant BTC chain. Pure "Nakamoto consensus" (if used as a governance philosophy) would do that.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @melikmanukyan @BTCSchellingPt @hodl_american I did not buy any BTC in 2017 or later.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: I continue to be worried about the fact that these wrapped BTC bridges are trusted.....  I hope that they can all *at least* move to a decently sized multisig

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: It's interesting how in the last few weeks I've argued with both pro-BTC *and* anti-BTC people who think BTC will utterly cripple nation state funding (pro-BTC ppl wanting to defund the militaries), while I disagree with both: I just don't think it will have that kind of effect.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: An article I wrote in 2017: Engineering Security Through Coordination Problems   https://t.co/dKve547Yof  This is a big part of my viewpoint for why full nodes and verification are important, though the arguments are quite different than what you often hear from eg. the BTC camp.  https://t.co/fZwiO8vftT

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @menotyoumenotyo @PaulRaj12000 @danheld Oh I meant the flavor of bitcoin.... it's the one that's not BTC or even BCH. ü§£

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @Excellion @tedmrogers @Obstropolos I have a wide probability distribution on the price of BTC (and other cryptos). Basically, we should be prepared for anything between significantly lower than today and multi-trillion-dollar market caps.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @Excellion @tedmrogers @Obstropolos (to anyone reading who hasn't done the math themselves Samson's number implies the BTC price is $2m)

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BryanJacoutot @zooko @owocki @zackvoell OK that's fair, then realistically a few (BTC, ETH, ETC until recently, likely a couple others I don't know about)

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BTCSocialist @Excellion Yep! There's plenty of capitalist techniques and plenty of socialist techniques employed by the BTC and ETH systems, and there's many ways that either system can be deployed for either capitalist or socialist ends.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BtcDoomGuy @Suheb__ @Excellion @pierre_rochard Basically, total amount created is fairly easy to compute, total amount destroyed is harder. And to be fair, no one knows how many BTC were destroyed either if you count all forms of destruction.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @billy_btc @2JohnGodden @pierre_rochard (unless by "all other things" you mean spent TXOs, but that's obviously not what you mean as spent TXOs are not part of the money supply and would actively confuse efforts to figure out the money supply)

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @billy_btc @2JohnGodden @pierre_rochard Correct, Bitcoin does not have this.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @billy_btc @2JohnGodden @pierre_rochard UTXOs are accounts, they're just one-time use.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @Pepe_BTC @ercwl Being a successful trader? Is that immoral now?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @Pepe_BTC @ercwl I mean those funds went to a bunch of eth2 client development, academic research, rollup development, privacy tech and other things that are directly connected to ethereum's recent successes..... if you want to call it "theft" feel free?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @kevinsekniqi @gladstein Actually I was arguing that it's wrong to claim that shilling ava is some kind of low dirty conflict-of-interest-laden activity but shilling btc is high minded and virtuous.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BlockGeekDima @IAmNickDodson @j6sp5r @ChrJentzsch @BTC_de_Blog @q9fmz (I think; I hope I don't get an egg-on-face here)

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BlockGeekDima @IAmNickDodson @j6sp5r @ChrJentzsch @BTC_de_Blog @q9fmz *das

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @j6sp5r @ChrJentzsch @BTC_de_Blog @q9fmz ETH1 wird automatisch ein shard von ETH2 werden; ein App muss nichts machen um von ETH1 nach ETH2 sich zu bewegen.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: If I were designing a new chain to live alongside bitcoin and ethereum, I would take *all* the political tradeoffs that BTC and ETH aren't willing to take.  * On-chain gov w QV * On-chain oracles for not just prices but arbitrary events * All the built-in cryptographic operations

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @ankurfr @hcarpach @safetyth1rd There's lots of ethereum things that are quite purist! Uniswap is a great example.  Meanwhile (some?) BTC people denigrate Uniswap as being "just shapeshift with atomic swaps". (If that's not you it would make me happy to hear it!)   https://t.co/tDLeQWOqgC

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @danheld @safetyth1rd > Premine = Early PoW participation  (i) this is a true moral equivalence, not a false one. (ii) I only ever said such things in response to BTC people saying "haha ETH premined shitcoin"  > ‚ÄúLower inflation‚Äù = Sound money  Lower inflation is sounder money!

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @danheld @safetyth1rd And (4) is, well, if you think responding to criticisms from BTC people counts as an attempt to destroy bitcoin, I don't know what to tell you

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @hcarpach @safetyth1rd I really and truly think it's the opposite. BTC people seem happy to have lots of centralized middlemen (bitmex, tether, liquid....) and it's the ETH community that's trying to decentralize these functions with smart contract constructions.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @kyletorpey @Muhd_Amrullah RSK is not built on bitcoin, it's a permissioned consortium chain that happens to use it as a base token.  BTC just does not have functionality escape velocity:  https://t.co/b3ViQRjIUp

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @JPloegman @timoncc I regrettably have not; ethereum itself is going in the BLS direction short-term (last time I talked to a BTC person, they said people are scared of extra assumptions in pairings; but you *do* gain a lot with BLS, like trivial aggregation for multisigs).

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @milner_aviv @CarlGocht Checks profile. Is surprised! My first guess for "Vitalik is a child" is BSV proponents. BTC probably would be second guess though.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @_prestwich @KamesCG Not perfectly but to a large extent yes. For example it is manifestly clear that the BCH community values cheap on-chain txs more than the BTC community does.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @lex_node I just think our existing blockchain governance experience (BTC block size, DAO fork, progpow....) shows that methods of aggregating feedback from larger groups are currently not sufficiently high-quality and we need effort on strengthening and improving them

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @canesin @achlem @nashsocial But if orders are published to a smart contract, how would someone on the BTC side publish an order? Or can BTC people with no ETH only claim existing orders?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @_prestwich @ameensol @sunnya97 @Theeylon @tzhen @summa_one It's also possible different models need to be tried. For example has anyone done the "I open a one-way BTC channel to you, you open a one-way ETH channel to me, we trade small increments at a time" approach?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: We should put resources toward a proper (trustless, serverless, maximally Uniswap-like UX) ETH <-> BTC decentralized exchange. It's embarrassing that we still can't easily move between the two largest crypto ecosystems trustlessly.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @seiff @jimmysong @Bitcoin > Printing money doesn‚Äôt require someone to buy it.  It actually does. "Buy" of course meaning "accept in exchange for products" in that context. And we've certainly seen cases where money quickly becomes worthless because people stop thinking it's a good place to keep value!

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @jimmysong @Bitcoin "If companies can just raise capital by issuing shares, why do they need revenue?"  (insert joke about how this is actually the SV model here)

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @bullofbtc @angela_walch Oh the BTC community is definitely on average more capitalist than the ETH community.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @icebearhww The answer to books vs music is different! Back in ~2011-12 I read the standard Austrian econ canon (Mises, Rothbard...) and that shaped my thinking a lot and made me appreciate BTC early on, though since then I've moved further away from that school of thought in particular

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @jemenger @ESYudkowsky @GiveWell But also important are "anti-influences", like seeing how toxic BTC maximalism was becoming even back in 2013 and wanting to build a culture that's far away from being like that.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @tylercowen The latter because I'm thinking about stablecoins. Some people think stablecoins are purely transition tech, and post-hypercryptoization BTC or ETH will be stable. I think there's a big chance this is wrong and even post-hypercryptoization we would still need explicit stablecoins

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @tylercowen I feel like I've been doing less "monetary theory" per se than a few years ago! I just don't rate it as anywhere close to the world's most important problem the way I would 10 years ago or the way many BTC people do today.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BitcoinMoon11 7 years ago, before ethereum even began, I had only a few thousand dollars of net worth. I nevertheless sold half my bitcoin to make sure that I would not be broke if BTC went to zero.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @GeorgeSelgin "Is BTC money" is not a question of economics, it's a question of signaling: "do bitcoiners get to plant their flag on this proud metaphorical hill where USD, EUR, CNY live"?  If you want to talk about economics, you have to credibly signal that you're not talking about the hill.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @JavierGonzalez @btcfork @CollinEnstad Yeah, I get that what I'm saying is the social contract of ETH, and it's not the social contract of BCH. It *is* arguably the social contract of BTC (see: their support of UASFs) though. And maybe it's the social contract of BCHA too?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @gladstein @deeeedle @lopp @twobitidiot @HRF Also there is a systemic concern: if the bulk of BTC economic activity is institutional then those institutions may well become a de facto governance layer and could be co-opted by nation state actors. Dissenters could fork off, but keep what percent of the value of their assets?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @mysticryuujin I think it's BTC people that call them lite.

tweet: @blogofjake > I was under the impression one would need to acquire >50% of all existing BTC  No. You only need to acquire an amount roughly equal to a few months to a year worth of mining revenue.

tweet: @austerity_sucks @zhusu I'm still pro-crypto because my own vision for what a crypto-dominant world would looks like does not involve crypto becoming the UoA. We already see things being paid in BTC/ETH but denominated in USD.

tweet: @awayslice There are many versions of USD, BTC and ETH on ethereum. Whichever you consider money you can use!

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BlockGeekDima @alexblue_99 @Bitcoin @ethereum Ah, but does it have constant-product post-neoliberal sharded hydroxychloroquine yield farming?

tweet: @Degenify The choice of BTC was deliberate; I'm trying out a hypothesis that bitcoin people specifically are more likely to interpret me as a socialist

tweet: Let me try a correlation poll.  1. Do you hold any BTC? (Y/N) 2. Do the ideas that I promote and seem to hold tend to be more capitalist (C) or socialist (S)?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @AriDavidPaul Agree it doesn't work with BTC and ETH and the like (heck, even BSV is still limping....). But it does work somewhat more with fly-by-night pyramid coins that appear quickly and die quickly.

tweet: @vinarmani @deadalnix > Nakamoto Consensus eliminates the necessity of a social contract. name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @melikmanukyan @BTCSchellingPt @hodl_american I did not buy any BTC in 2017 or later.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: I continue to be worried about the fact that these wrapped BTC bridges are trusted.....  I hope that they can all *at least* move to a decently sized multisig

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: It's interesting how in the last few weeks I've argued with both pro-BTC *and* anti-BTC people who think BTC will utterly cripple nation state funding (pro-BTC ppl wanting to defund the militaries), while I disagree with both: I just don't think it will have that kind of effect.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: An article I wrote in 2017: Engineering Security Through Coordination Problems   https://t.co/dKve547Yof  This is a big part of my viewpoint for why full nodes and verification are important, though the arguments are quite different than what you often hear from eg. the BTC camp.  https://t.co/fZwiO8vftT

tweet: @BTCSocialist @Excellion Yep! There's plenty of capitalist techniques and plenty of socialist techniques employed by the BTC and ETH systems, and there's many ways that either system can be deployed for either capitalist or socialist ends.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @BitcoinMoon11 7 years ago, before ethereum even began, I had only a few thousand dollars of net worth. I nevertheless sold half my bitcoin to make sure that I would not be broke if BTC went to zero.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @GeorgeSelgin "Is BTC money" is not a question of economics, it's a question of signaling: "do bitcoiners get to plant their flag on this proud metaphorical hill where USD, EUR, CNY live"?  If you want to talk about economics, you have to credibly signal that you're not talking about the hill.

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @JavierGonzalez @btcfork @CollinEnstad Yeah, I get that what I'm saying is the social contract of ETH, and it's not the social contract of BCH. It *is* arguably the social contract of BTC (see: their support of UASFs) though. And maybe it's the social contract of BCHA too?

name: vitalik.eth
tweet: @gladstein @deeeedle @lopp @twobitidiot @HRF Also there is a systemic concern: if the bulk of BTC economic activity is institutional then those institutions may well become a de facto governance layer and could be co-opted by nation state actors. Dissenters could fork off, but keep what percent of the value of their assets?
